text: :popcorn:

Ok, the two are students/phd/postdocs/similar at the University Teheran/Iran. So, there may be some underlying traumas which results in some pronounced vulnerability when it comes to discussion with a community which is mainly driven by western and privileged people (viewed from their point of view). Of course, speculation, but I say that, because I am thinking about the previous discussions we had about inclusiveness and being open as a community, and how difficult those discussions have been, and I already mentioned the one which has banned, who acted similar. As we are mainly focusing on technical aspects and questions, it is quite a challenge to be simultaneously sensitive and open, if the counterpart perhaps brings a load of invisible self-experienced insults (I mean mental wounds here), which can be triggered so easily. Of course, we can't solve this issue, and who is "we" in this thoughts. For me I can tell, that I can't solve it for myself, as I will sometimes fall again into this trap, without wanting to, but than it's too late, the counterpart is offended and thinking back, the signs have been there but I missed them. We already have some experience with these discussions, which go wrong. <@U6740K1SP> felt the direction and slowed the discussion down, which again offended OP. So, the sensors seem already in place, but how to act on these sensors? Perhaps we need a really moderated space, where every post has to be approved, before it goes online. Approving the posts would be to check against hidden accusations, hidden personal afronts and alike, which may trigger the wrong direction. This would be work, and should not only be done by stewards, perhaps another new gremium to approve posts in this moderated space. When sensors giving alarm, the discussion could be paused, OP could be asked if it is ok to be moved into moderated space/mode. If no, give it a chance, until sensors ring again. Second time is a forced moderated mode. It must be made clear that moderation mode is not a offence against the OP but a countermeasure against offences. Would such a system be recognised as a way to be open in difficult situations or would it be seen as another way to shutting people down? Well, these are the edge cases of an open community. The community, the stewards and especially <@U6795JH6H> do a really good job here (again), but the overall issue stays unsolved, and the people involved will again struggle in the next case, which will come.

text: Well, I like this Julia community. I don't think we are somehow exclusive or closed. Of course, the smaller a community, the less heterogen it is. I believe the character of a strawman article is apparent for all readers, it's easy to see through it.

text: At this point I have started neglecting the “Python cult” people. There is no way we are going to convince them and *we shouldn’t spend time convincing them.* Most of these people start with a preconceived state and they are only looking for “superficial cues” to strengthen their own bias. These critiques are mostly conservative and skeptics who just need another reason not to learn a new language and stick onto the status quo. Though Julia is mature enough, I would still say it favors the innovators and visionaries at this point. Moreover, anyone who has spent “some” time trying serious computational modeling work in Julia will notice Julia’s strength over other languages!

text: I wonder why some people who tried Julia for a very short time are drawn to the discourse platform to voice their opinions in a manner that sounds like "in order to convince me as a user you should do x y z" where x y z are usually very well known. Also who would be the "you" in this case, the Julia community has so many members that contribute. So these posters sometimes have no interest in hearing about solutions or workarounds, they just want to be validated for their newly minted opinion. Which is fine I guess, but it's not surprising that this leads to conflicts with community members who have no interest in being told why other ecosystems are better and will be better in the foreseeable future

text:
I don't think it's that hard to empathize with Pythonistas who dislike Julia. They are passionate and defensive about their language - a sentiment many of us ought to empathize with. They've probably been using Python with success for years, so it grinds them the wrong way when people imply that Python is obsolete or a poor choice. They might even have tried Julia and hit some difficulty (such as the recurring Pkg issues I hear about, and sometimes experience), then gotten frustrated and quit.
When transitioning from Python to Julia, I remember myself having a phase where I got fed up with Julia's idiosyncracies - but I just *had* to preservere and keep learning, because I needed the performance, so giving up wasn't really an option. I actually think I still have a `why_julia_sucks.txt` file somewhere, and I know for sure I have a Jupyter notebook with Python tricks and performance tips to make Python's performance match or exceed Julia.

text: I was also fed up with Julia multiple times, but kind of coped with whatever I didn't like because in general the language resonated much more with me than Python or R or Matlab. I also often think the messaging regarding the superior speed could be toned down, or at least always go hand in hand with larger startup and compilation cost. Because that definitely has a large impact for many workflows people are used to, and it's fair to criticize it. But I also recognize a lot of what HN posters might call "messaging" is just people's opinions and not a centralized effort by some entity so if they get upset at "the higher ups" I find that a bit ridiculous

text:
If I had some work to do in the area where I feel Julia concentrates on, which I think is solving differential equations and creating new ML algorithms with AD, Julia would be my first choice. I’m not sure where exactly Julia would be my first choice, but there are things that are a bit hazy for me, but which would be of interest.
Handling data that’s bigger than fits on my laptop. a) 100 GB - 1 TB area, b) true bigdata. I believe this is not currently Julia’s strength. I probably did something wrong, but I tried to handle some data that’s around 100GB, and Julia crawled to a halt while Python/Dask was just finished already.
Visualization. Julia has packages for this, but I believe without know exactly that they’re OK, but not great, first class, best in the world.
Web serving. Again an area where I perceive Julia as being OK, but not great.
After spending quite a lot of time for this since last Fall, this is basically my view on Julia: most things are OK, but not the best choice you could make, with the exception of pure computation.

text:
I find that for somebody criticising Julia in a forum, it is too easy to upset the community. Let em criticise! We must not comment on every criticism. Receive the criticism showing some interest, but don’t care so much for it that you get upset. The damage of such heated debates is just too much for everybody.

Sometimes I feel that we are too thin-skinned.

text:
Yes, this is true, it was obvious that he was very thin-skinned and that his tone was an angry one. It is difficult to respond to someone like that in a civil manner. Easier said than done, I know.

But known criticisms or objections maybe could be handled in a more rational way, something like a FAQ or a FFO (frequently filed objections) where people can be pointed to. Something that shows that we are aware of their objections and that they are worked on and that there are demonstrable improvements.

text: I now had the time to read 'julia-a-post-mortem' and it makes me angry. First it's way too long for what it contains. But second, more important: The author makes up a general claim, in this case "Instead of becoming _the_ language", which was never claimed by anyone, as far as I remember, and then the author starts to disprove the claim, he made up himself. After reading all this through, and I had a hard time when it comes to "Lucius Cassius", I am angry now. :angry: Someone wants to look clever, but this someone just stole my time. There are some interesting and true points in this article, but the most are from other authors and just quoted.
